segment.source: Use out-of-date ActiveX control blocking to help you know when IE prevents a webpage from loading outdated ActiveX controls and to update the outdated control, so that it’s safer to use.
segment.target: Use out-of-date ActiveX control blocking to help you know when IE prevents a webpage from loading outdated ActiveX controls and to update the outdated control, so that it’s safer to use.

segment.source: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)
segment.target: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)

segment.source: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking
segment.target: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking

segment.source: Applies to:
segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 8.1
segment.target: Windows 8.1

segment.source: Windows 7
segment.target: Windows 7

segment.source: Windows Server 2012 R2
segment.target: Windows Server 2012 R2

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 R2 with Service Pack 1 (SP1)
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 R2 with Service Pack 1 (SP1)

segment.source: Windows Vista SP2
segment.target: Windows Vista SP2

segment.source: ActiveX controls are small apps that let websites provide content, like videos, games, and let you interact with content like toolbars.
segment.target: ActiveX controls are small apps that let websites provide content, like videos, games, and let you interact with content like toolbars.

segment.source: Unfortunately, because many ActiveX controls aren’t automatically updated, they can become outdated as new versions are released.
segment.target: Unfortunately, because many ActiveX controls aren’t automatically updated, they can become outdated as new versions are released.

segment.source: It’s very important that you keep your ActiveX controls up-to-date because malicious software (or malware) can target security flaws in outdated controls, damaging your computer by collecting info from it, installing unwanted software, or by letting someone else control it remotely.
segment.target: It’s very important that you keep your ActiveX controls up-to-date because malicious software (or malware) can target security flaws in outdated controls, damaging your computer by collecting info from it, installing unwanted software, or by letting someone else control it remotely.

segment.source: To help avoid this situation, Internet Explorer includes a new security feature, called out-of-date ActiveX control blocking.
segment.target: To help avoid this situation, Internet Explorer includes a new security feature, called out-of-date ActiveX control blocking.

segment.source: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking lets you:
segment.target: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking lets you:

segment.source: Know when IE prevents a webpage from loading common, but outdated ActiveX controls.
segment.target: Know when IE prevents a webpage from loading common, but outdated ActiveX controls.

segment.source: Interact with other parts of the webpage that aren’t affected by the outdated control.
segment.target: Interact with other parts of the webpage that aren’t affected by the outdated control.

segment.source: Update the outdated control, so that it’s up-to-date and safer to use.
segment.target: Update the outdated control, so that it’s up-to-date and safer to use.

segment.source: The out-of-date ActiveX control blocking feature works with all Security Zones, except the Local Intranet Zone and the Trusted Sites Zone.
segment.target: The out-of-date ActiveX control blocking feature works with all Security Zones, except the Local Intranet Zone and the Trusted Sites Zone.

segment.source: It also works with these operating system and IE combinations:
segment.target: It also works with these operating system and IE combinations:

segment.source: Windows operating system
segment.target: Windows operating system

segment.source: IE version
segment.target: IE version

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: All supported versions of IE.
segment.target: All supported versions of IE.

segment.source: Microsoft Edge doesn't support ActiveX controls.
segment.target: Microsoft Edge doesn't support ActiveX controls.

segment.source: Windows 8.1 and Windows 8.1 Update
segment.target: Windows 8.1 and Windows 8.1 Update

segment.source: All supported versions of IE
segment.target: All supported versions of IE

segment.source: Windows 7 SP1
segment.target: Windows 7 SP1

segment.source: All supported versions of IE
segment.target: All supported versions of IE

segment.source: Windows Server 2012
segment.target: Windows Server 2012

segment.source: All supported versions of IE
segment.target: All supported versions of IE

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 R2 SP1
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 R2 SP1

segment.source: All supported versions of IE
segment.target: All supported versions of IE

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 SP2
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 SP2

segment.source: Windows Internet Explorer 9 only
segment.target: Windows Internet Explorer 9 only

segment.source: Windows Vista SP2
segment.target: Windows Vista SP2

segment.source: Windows Internet Explorer 9 only
segment.target: Windows Internet Explorer 9 only

segment.source: For more info about this new feature, see the Internet Explorer begins blocking out-of-date ActiveX controls blog.
segment.target: For more info about this new feature, see the Internet Explorer begins blocking out-of-date ActiveX controls blog.

segment.source: To see the complete list of out-of-date Active controls blocked by this feature, see Blocked out-of-date ActiveX controls.
segment.target: To see the complete list of out-of-date Active controls blocked by this feature, see Blocked out-of-date ActiveX controls.

segment.source: What does the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking notification look like?
segment.target: What does the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking notification look like?

segment.source: When IE blocks an outdated ActiveX control, you’ll see a notification bar similar to this, depending on your version of IE:
segment.target: When IE blocks an outdated ActiveX control, you’ll see a notification bar similar to this, depending on your version of IE:

segment.source: Internet Explorer 9 through Internet Explorer 11
segment.target: Internet Explorer 9 through Internet Explorer 11

segment.source: Warning about outdated activex controls (ie9+)
segment.target: Warning about outdated activex controls (ie9+)

segment.source: Windows Internet Explorer 8
segment.target: Windows Internet Explorer 8

segment.source: Warning about outdated activex controls (ie8)
segment.target: Warning about outdated activex controls (ie8)

segment.source: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking also gives you a security warning that tells you if a webpage tries to launch specific outdated apps, outside of IE:
segment.target: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking also gives you a security warning that tells you if a webpage tries to launch specific outdated apps, outside of IE:

segment.source: Warning about outdated activex controls outside ie
segment.target: Warning about outdated activex controls outside ie

segment.source: How do I fix an outdated ActiveX control or app?
segment.target: How do I fix an outdated ActiveX control or app?

segment.source: From the notification about the outdated ActiveX control, you can go to the control’s website to download its latest version.
segment.target: From the notification about the outdated ActiveX control, you can go to the control’s website to download its latest version.

segment.source: To get the updated ActiveX control
segment.target: To get the updated ActiveX control

segment.source: From the notification bar, tap or click Update.
segment.target: From the notification bar, tap or click Update.

segment.source: IE opens the ActiveX control’s website.
segment.target: IE opens the ActiveX control’s website.

segment.source: Download the latest version of the control.
segment.target: Download the latest version of the control.

segment.source: Security Note:
segment.target: Security Note:

segment.source: If you don’t fully trust a site, you shouldn’t allow it to load an outdated ActiveX control.
segment.target: If you don’t fully trust a site, you shouldn’t allow it to load an outdated ActiveX control.

segment.source: However, although we don’t recommend it, you can view the missing webpage content by tapping or clicking Run this time.
segment.target: However, although we don’t recommend it, you can view the missing webpage content by tapping or clicking Run this time.

segment.source: This option runs the ActiveX control without updating or fixing the problem.
segment.target: This option runs the ActiveX control without updating or fixing the problem.

segment.source: The next time you visit a webpage running the same outdated ActiveX control, you’ll get the notification again.
segment.target: The next time you visit a webpage running the same outdated ActiveX control, you’ll get the notification again.

segment.source: To get the updated app
segment.target: To get the updated app

segment.source: From the security warning, tap or click Update link.
segment.target: From the security warning, tap or click Update link.

segment.source: IE opens the app’s website.
segment.target: IE opens the app’s website.

segment.source: Download the latest version of the app.
segment.target: Download the latest version of the app.

segment.source: Security Note:
segment.target: Security Note:

segment.source: If you don’t fully trust a site, you shouldn’t allow it to launch an outdated app.
segment.target: If you don’t fully trust a site, you shouldn’t allow it to launch an outdated app.

segment.source: However, although we don’t recommend it, you can let the webpage launch the app by tapping or clicking Allow.
segment.target: However, although we don’t recommend it, you can let the webpage launch the app by tapping or clicking Allow.

segment.source: This option opens the app without updating or fixing the problem.
segment.target: This option opens the app without updating or fixing the problem.

segment.source: The next time you visit a webpage running the same outdated app, you’ll get the notification again.
segment.target: The next time you visit a webpage running the same outdated app, you’ll get the notification again.

segment.source: How does IE decide which ActiveX controls to block?
segment.target: How does IE decide which ActiveX controls to block?

segment.source: IE uses Microsoft’s versionlist.xml or versionlistWin7.xml file to determine whether an ActiveX control should be stopped from loading.
segment.target: IE uses Microsoft’s versionlist.xml or versionlistWin7.xml file to determine whether an ActiveX control should be stopped from loading.

segment.source: These files are updated with newly-discovered out-of-date ActiveX controls, which IE automatically downloads to your local copy of the file.
segment.target: These files are updated with newly-discovered out-of-date ActiveX controls, which IE automatically downloads to your local copy of the file.

segment.source: You can see your copy of the file here or you can view Microsoft’s version, based on your operating system and version of IE, here:
segment.target: You can see your copy of the file here or you can view Microsoft’s version, based on your operating system and version of IE, here:

segment.source: Internet Explorer 11 on Windows 7 SP1 or Windows Server 2008 R2
segment.target: Internet Explorer 11 on Windows 7 SP1 or Windows Server 2008 R2

segment.source: All other configurations
segment.target: All other configurations

segment.source: Security Note:
segment.target: Security Note:

segment.source: Although we strongly recommend against it, if you don’t want your computer to automatically download the updated version list from Microsoft, run the following command from a command prompt:
segment.target: Although we strongly recommend against it, if you don’t want your computer to automatically download the updated version list from Microsoft, run the following command from a command prompt:

segment.source: Turning off this automatic download breaks the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking feature by not letting the version list update with newly outdated controls, potentially compromising the security of your computer.
segment.target: Turning off this automatic download breaks the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking feature by not letting the version list update with newly outdated controls, potentially compromising the security of your computer.

segment.source: Use this configuration option at your own risk.
segment.target: Use this configuration option at your own risk.

segment.source: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking on managed devices
segment.target: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking on managed devices

segment.source: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking includes 4 new Group Policy settings that you can use to manage your web browser configuration, based on your domain controller.
segment.target: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking includes 4 new Group Policy settings that you can use to manage your web browser configuration, based on your domain controller.

segment.source: You can download the administrative templates, including the new settings, from the Administrative templates (.admx) for Windows 10 page or the Administrative Templates (.admx) for Windows 8.1 and Windows Server 2012 R2 page, depending on your operating system.
segment.target: You can download the administrative templates, including the new settings, from the Administrative templates (.admx) for Windows 10 page or the Administrative Templates (.admx) for Windows 8.1 and Windows Server 2012 R2 page, depending on your operating system.

segment.source: Group Policy settings
segment.target: Group Policy settings

segment.source: Here’s a list of the new Group Policy info, including the settings, location, requirements, and Help text strings.
segment.target: Here’s a list of the new Group Policy info, including the settings, location, requirements, and Help text strings.

segment.source: All of these settings can be set in either the Computer Configuration or User Configuration scope, but Computer Configuration takes precedence over User Configuration.
segment.target: All of these settings can be set in either the Computer Configuration or User Configuration scope, but Computer Configuration takes precedence over User Configuration.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking is turned off in the Local Intranet Zone and the Trusted Sites Zone; therefore, intranet websites and line-of-business apps will continue to use out-of-date ActiveX controls without disruption.
segment.target: Out-of-date ActiveX control blocking is turned off in the Local Intranet Zone and the Trusted Sites Zone; therefore, intranet websites and line-of-business apps will continue to use out-of-date ActiveX controls without disruption.

segment.source: Setting
segment.target: Setting

segment.source: Category path
segment.target: Category path

segment.source: Supported on
segment.target: Supported on

segment.source: Help text
segment.target: Help text

segment.source: Turn on ActiveX control logging in IE
segment.target: Turn on ActiveX control logging in IE

segment.source: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11
segment.target: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11

segment.source: This setting determines whether IE saves log information for ActiveX controls.
segment.target: This setting determines whether IE saves log information for ActiveX controls.

segment.source: If you enable this setting, IE logs ActiveX control information (including the source URI that loaded the control and whether it was blocked) to a local file.
segment.target: If you enable this setting, IE logs ActiveX control information (including the source URI that loaded the control and whether it was blocked) to a local file.

segment.source: If you disable or don't configure this setting, IE won't log ActiveX control information.
segment.target: If you disable or don't configure this setting, IE won't log ActiveX control information.

segment.source: Note that you can turn this setting on or off regardless of the Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE or Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE on specific domains settings.
segment.target: Note that you can turn this setting on or off regardless of the Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE or Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE on specific domains settings.

segment.source: Remove the Run this time button for outdated ActiveX controls in IE
segment.target: Remove the Run this time button for outdated ActiveX controls in IE

segment.source: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11
segment.target: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11

segment.source: This setting allows you stop users from seeing the Run this time button and from running specific outdated ActiveX controls in IE.
segment.target: This setting allows you stop users from seeing the Run this time button and from running specific outdated ActiveX controls in IE.

segment.source: If you enable this setting, users won't see the Run this time button on the warning message that appears when IE blocks an outdated ActiveX control.
segment.target: If you enable this setting, users won't see the Run this time button on the warning message that appears when IE blocks an outdated ActiveX control.

segment.source: If you disable or don't configure this setting, users will see the Run this time button on the warning message that appears when IE blocks an outdated ActiveX control.
segment.target: If you disable or don't configure this setting, users will see the Run this time button on the warning message that appears when IE blocks an outdated ActiveX control.

segment.source: Clicking this button lets the user run the outdated ActiveX control once.
segment.target: Clicking this button lets the user run the outdated ActiveX control once.

segment.source: Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE on specific domains
segment.target: Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE on specific domains

segment.source: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11
segment.target: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11

segment.source: This setting allows you to manage a list of domains on which IE will stop blocking outdated ActiveX controls.
segment.target: This setting allows you to manage a list of domains on which IE will stop blocking outdated ActiveX controls.

segment.source: Outdated ActiveX controls are never blocked in the Intranet Zone.
segment.target: Outdated ActiveX controls are never blocked in the Intranet Zone.

segment.source: If you enable this setting, you can enter a custom list of domains for which outdated ActiveX controls won't be blocked in IE.
segment.target: If you enable this setting, you can enter a custom list of domains for which outdated ActiveX controls won't be blocked in IE.

segment.source: Each domain entry must be formatted like one of the following:
segment.target: Each domain entry must be formatted like one of the following:

segment.source: "domainname.TLD".
segment.target: "domainname.TLD".

segment.source: For example, if you want to include , use "contoso.com".
segment.target: For example, if you want to include , use "contoso.com".

segment.source: "hostname".
segment.target: "hostname".

segment.source: For example, if you want to include , use "example".
segment.target: For example, if you want to include , use "example".

segment.source: "file:///path/filename.htm".
segment.target: "file:///path/filename.htm".

segment.source: For example, use .
segment.target: For example, use .

segment.source: If you disable or don't configure this setting, the list is deleted and IE continues to block specific outdated ActiveX controls on all domains in the Internet Zone.
segment.target: If you disable or don't configure this setting, the list is deleted and IE continues to block specific outdated ActiveX controls on all domains in the Internet Zone.

segment.source: Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE
segment.target: Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE

segment.source: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11
segment.target: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11

segment.source: This setting determines whether IE blocks specific outdated ActiveX controls.
segment.target: This setting determines whether IE blocks specific outdated ActiveX controls.

segment.source: Outdated ActiveX controls are never blocked in the Intranet Zone.
segment.target: Outdated ActiveX controls are never blocked in the Intranet Zone.

segment.source: If you enable this setting, IE stops blocking outdated ActiveX controls.
segment.target: If you enable this setting, IE stops blocking outdated ActiveX controls.

segment.source: If you disable or don't configure this setting, IE continues to block specific outdated ActiveX controls.
segment.target: If you disable or don't configure this setting, IE continues to block specific outdated ActiveX controls.

segment.source: Remove the Update button in the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking notification for IE
segment.target: Remove the Update button in the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking notification for IE

segment.source: This functionality is only available through the registry
segment.target: This functionality is only available through the registry

segment.source: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11
segment.target: Internet Explorer 8 through IE11

segment.source: This setting determines whether the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking notification shows the Update button.
segment.target: This setting determines whether the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking notification shows the Update button.

segment.source: This button points users to update specific out-of-date ActiveX controls in IE.
segment.target: This button points users to update specific out-of-date ActiveX controls in IE.

segment.source: If you don't want to use Group Policy, you can also turn these settings on or off using the registry.
segment.target: If you don't want to use Group Policy, you can also turn these settings on or off using the registry.

segment.source: You can update the registry manually.
segment.target: You can update the registry manually.

segment.target: Setting

segment.target: Turn on ActiveX control logging in IE

segment.target: Where:

segment.target: Logs ActiveX control information (including the source URI that loaded the control and whether it was blocked) to a local file.

segment.source: 1. Logs ActiveX control information.

segment.target: Remove Run this time button for outdated ActiveX controls in IE

segment.target: Where:

segment.target: 0. Removes the Run this time button.

segment.target: 1 or not configured.

segment.source: Leaves the Run this time button.
segment.target: Leaves the Run this time button.

segment.target: Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE on specific domains

segment.target: Where:

segment.source: contoso.com.
segment.target: contoso.com.

segment.source: A single domain on which outdated ActiveX controls won't be blocked in IE.
segment.target: A single domain on which outdated ActiveX controls won't be blocked in IE.

segment.source: Use a new command for each domain you wish to add to the Allow list.
segment.target: Use a new command for each domain you wish to add to the Allow list.

segment.source: Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE
segment.target: Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE

segment.source: Where:
segment.target: Where:

segment.source: 0. Stops blocking outdated ActiveX controls.
segment.target: 0. Stops blocking outdated ActiveX controls.

segment.source: 1 or not configured.
segment.target: 1 or not configured.

segment.source: Continues to block specific outdated ActiveX controls.
segment.target: Continues to block specific outdated ActiveX controls.

segment.source: Remove the Update button in the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking notification for IE
segment.target: Remove the Update button in the out-of-date ActiveX control blocking notification for IE

segment.source: Where:
segment.target: Where:

segment.source: 0. Removes the Update button
segment.target: 0. Removes the Update button

segment.target: 1 or not configured.

segment.source: Leaves the Update button.
segment.target: Leaves the Update button.

segment.source: Inventory your ActiveX controls
segment.target: Inventory your ActiveX controls

segment.source: You can inventory the ActiveX controls being used in your company, by turning on the Turn on ActiveX control logging in IE setting:
segment.target: You can inventory the ActiveX controls being used in your company, by turning on the Turn on ActiveX control logging in IE setting:

segment.source: Windows 10: Through a comma-separated values (.csv) file or through a local Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) class.
segment.target: Windows 10: Through a comma-separated values (.csv) file or through a local Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) class.

segment.source: All other versions of Microsoft Windows: Through a .csv file only.
segment.target: All other versions of Microsoft Windows: Through a .csv file only.

segment.source: Inventory your ActiveX controls by using a .CSV file
segment.target: Inventory your ActiveX controls by using a .CSV file

segment.source: If you decide to inventory the ActiveX controls being used in your company by turning on the Turn on ActiveX control logging in IE setting, IE logs the ActiveX control information to the file.
segment.target: If you decide to inventory the ActiveX controls being used in your company by turning on the Turn on ActiveX control logging in IE setting, IE logs the ActiveX control information to the file.

segment.source: Here’s a detailed example and description of what’s included in the VersionAuditLog.csv file.
segment.target: Here’s a detailed example and description of what’s included in the VersionAuditLog.csv file.

segment.target: Source URI

segment.target: File path

segment.target: Allowed/Blocked

segment.target: EPM-compatible

segment.target: C:\Windows\System32\Macromed\Flash\Flash.ocx

segment.target: Allowed

segment.target: Not in blocklist

segment.target: C:\Program Files\Java\jre6\bin\jp2iexp.dll

segment.source: Blocked
segment.target: Blocked

segment.source: Out of date
segment.target: Out of date

segment.source: Not EPM-compatible
segment.target: Not EPM-compatible

segment.source: Where:
segment.target: Where:

segment.source: Source URI.
segment.target: Source URI.

segment.source: The URL of the page that loaded the ActiveX control.
segment.target: The URL of the page that loaded the ActiveX control.

segment.source: File path.
segment.target: File path.

segment.source: The location of the binary that implements the ActiveX control.
segment.target: The location of the binary that implements the ActiveX control.

segment.source: Product version.
segment.target: Product version.

segment.source: The product version of the binary that implements the ActiveX control.
segment.target: The product version of the binary that implements the ActiveX control.

segment.source: File version.
segment.target: File version.

segment.source: The file version of the binary that implements the ActiveX control.
segment.target: The file version of the binary that implements the ActiveX control.

segment.source: Allowed/Blocked Whether IE blocked the ActiveX control.
segment.target: Allowed/Blocked Whether IE blocked the ActiveX control.

segment.source: Enhanced Protected Mode (EPM)-compatible.
segment.target: Enhanced Protected Mode (EPM)-compatible.

segment.source: Whether the loaded ActiveX control is compatible with Enhanced Protected Mode.
segment.target: Whether the loaded ActiveX control is compatible with Enhanced Protected Mode.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Enhanced Protected Mode isn’t supported on Internet Explorer 9 or earlier versions of IE.
segment.target: Enhanced Protected Mode isn’t supported on Internet Explorer 9 or earlier versions of IE.

segment.source: Therefore, if you’re using Internet Explorer 8 or Internet Explorer 9, all ActiveX controls will always be marked as not EPM-compatible.
segment.target: Therefore, if you’re using Internet Explorer 8 or Internet Explorer 9, all ActiveX controls will always be marked as not EPM-compatible.

segment.source: Reason.
segment.target: Reason.

segment.source: The ActiveX control can be blocked or allowed for any of these reasons:
segment.target: The ActiveX control can be blocked or allowed for any of these reasons:

segment.source: Reason
segment.target: Reason

segment.source: Corresponds to
segment.target: Corresponds to

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Version not in blocklist
segment.target: Version not in blocklist

segment.source: Allowed
segment.target: Allowed

segment.source: The version of the loaded ActiveX control is explicitly allowed by the IE version list.
segment.target: The version of the loaded ActiveX control is explicitly allowed by the IE version list.

segment.source: Trusted domain
segment.target: Trusted domain

segment.source: Allowed
segment.target: Allowed

segment.source: The ActiveX control was loaded on a domain listed in the Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE on specific domains setting.
segment.target: The ActiveX control was loaded on a domain listed in the Turn off blocking of outdated ActiveX controls for IE on specific domains setting.

segment.source: File doesn’t exist
segment.target: File doesn’t exist

segment.source: Allowed
segment.target: Allowed

segment.source: The loaded ActiveX control is missing required binaries to run correctly.
segment.target: The loaded ActiveX control is missing required binaries to run correctly.

segment.source: Out-of-date
segment.target: Out-of-date

segment.source: Blocked
segment.target: Blocked

segment.source: The loaded ActiveX control is explicitly blocked by the IE version list because it is out-of-date.
segment.target: The loaded ActiveX control is explicitly blocked by the IE version list because it is out-of-date.

segment.source: Not in blocklist
segment.target: Not in blocklist

segment.source: Allowed
segment.target: Allowed

segment.source: The loaded ActiveX control isn’t in the IE version list.
segment.target: The loaded ActiveX control isn’t in the IE version list.

segment.source: Managed by policy
segment.target: Managed by policy

segment.source: Allowed
segment.target: Allowed

segment.source: The loaded ActiveX control is managed by a Group Policy setting that isn’t listed here, and will be managed in accordance with that Group Policy setting.
segment.target: The loaded ActiveX control is managed by a Group Policy setting that isn’t listed here, and will be managed in accordance with that Group Policy setting.

segment.source: Trusted Site Zone or intranet
segment.target: Trusted Site Zone or intranet

segment.source: Allowed
segment.target: Allowed

segment.source: The ActiveX control was loaded in the Trusted Sites Zone or the Local Intranet Zone.
segment.target: The ActiveX control was loaded in the Trusted Sites Zone or the Local Intranet Zone.

segment.source: Hardblocked
segment.target: Hardblocked

segment.source: Blocked
segment.target: Blocked

segment.source: The loaded ActiveX control is blocked in IE because it contains known security vulnerabilities.
segment.target: The loaded ActiveX control is blocked in IE because it contains known security vulnerabilities.

segment.source: Unknown
segment.target: Unknown

segment.source: Allowed or blocked
segment.target: Allowed or blocked

segment.source: None of the above apply.
segment.target: None of the above apply.

segment.source: Inventory your ActiveX controls by using a local WMI class
segment.target: Inventory your ActiveX controls by using a local WMI class

segment.source: For Windows 10 you also have the option to log your inventory info to a local WMI class.
segment.target: For Windows 10 you also have the option to log your inventory info to a local WMI class.

segment.source: Info logged to this class includes all of info you get from the .csv file, plus the CLSID of the loaded ActiveX control or the name of any apps started from an ActiveX control.
segment.target: Info logged to this class includes all of info you get from the .csv file, plus the CLSID of the loaded ActiveX control or the name of any apps started from an ActiveX control.

segment.source: Before you begin
segment.target: Before you begin

segment.source: Before you can use WMI to inventory your ActiveX controls, you need to download the configuration package (.zip file), which includes:
segment.target: Before you can use WMI to inventory your ActiveX controls, you need to download the configuration package (.zip file), which includes:

segment.source: ConfigureWMILogging.ps1.
segment.target: ConfigureWMILogging.ps1.

segment.source: A Windows PowerShell script.
segment.target: A Windows PowerShell script.

segment.source: ActiveXWMILogging.mof.
segment.target: ActiveXWMILogging.mof.

segment.source: A managed object file.
segment.target: A managed object file.

segment.source: Before running the PowerShell script, you must copy both the .ps1 and .mof file to the same directory location, on the client computer.
segment.target: Before running the PowerShell script, you must copy both the .ps1 and .mof file to the same directory location, on the client computer.

segment.source: To configure IE to use WMI logging
segment.target: To configure IE to use WMI logging

originalData.data: `Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Turn on ActiveX control logging in IE`

segment.source: Open your Group Policy editor and turn on the setting.
segment.target: Open your Group Policy editor and turn on the setting.

segment.source: On the client device, start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run by by-passing the PowerShell execution policy, using this command:
segment.target: On the client device, start PowerShell in elevated mode (using admin privileges) and run by by-passing the PowerShell execution policy, using this command:

segment.source: For more info, see about_Execution_Policies.
segment.target: For more info, see about_Execution_Policies.

segment.source: Optional: Set up your domain firewall for WMI data.
segment.target: Optional: Set up your domain firewall for WMI data.

segment.source: For more info, see Collect data using Enterprise Site Discovery.
segment.target: For more info, see Collect data using Enterprise Site Discovery.

segment.source: The inventory info appears in the WMI class, , located in the WMI namespace, rootcimv2IETelemetry.
segment.target: The inventory info appears in the WMI class, , located in the WMI namespace, rootcimv2IETelemetry.

segment.source: To collect the inventory info from your client computers, we recommend using System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager or any agent that can access the WMI data.
segment.target: To collect the inventory info from your client computers, we recommend using System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager or any agent that can access the WMI data.

segment.source: For more info, see Collect data using Enterprise Site Discovery.
segment.target: For more info, see Collect data using Enterprise Site Discovery.
